title: 112_hr6658
content: The Urban Competitiveness Act, also known as the Zero Capital Gains Rate for Certain New Investments in Specified Areas, introduces a provision for a zero capital gains rate for certain new investments in specified areas under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Urban Competitiveness Act introduces a provision for a zero capital gains rate for qualified capital gain from the sale or exchange of specified new investments held for more than 1 year, including qualified stock, partnership interest, and business property. The Urban Competitiveness Act allows for a zero capital gains rate on qualified capital gains from specified new investments, including qualified stock, partnership interest, and business property, held for over a year. The Act also outlines conditions for issuing stock to a corporation in exchange for cash, with requirements related to the corporation being a specified area business and meeting certain criteria during the taxpayer's holding period. The term 'qualified partnership interest' refers to a capital or profits interest acquired within a year of the enactment of the section, solely in exchange for cash from a domestic partnership that is a specified area business. The term 'qualified partnership interest' refers to a capital or profits interest acquired within a year of the enactment of the section, solely in exchange for cash from a domestic partnership that is a specified area business. For such interest, the partnership qualifies as a specified area business. The term 'qualified business property' refers to tangible property acquired by the taxpayer through purchase during the 1-year period after the enactment of this section, with the original use of the property in the specified area starting with the taxpayer. During the holding period for such property, specific conditions must be met. The taxpayer's holding period for property in a specified area business must meet certain conditions. Substantial improvements by the taxpayer before a specified period and the location of the property are considered. The determination of substantial improvement follows specific guidelines. The term 'qualified capital gain' is defined as any gain recognized on the sale or exchange of a capital asset or property used in the trade or business. This definition excludes any gain attributable to periods before the enactment of the section. Additionally, rules similar to those in section 1400B(e) apply. For purposes of this section, a 'specified area business' is defined as any enterprise zone business, with specific criteria adjustments. A 'specified area' is defined as any principal city of a metropolitan statistical area with certain unemployment rate criteria. The section outlines criteria for a specified area business, including high unemployment rates and population loss. Regulations will be prescribed by the Secretary to carry out the purposes of this section. The Secretary will prescribe regulations to prevent abuse of the purposes outlined for specified area businesses in subchapter Y of chapter 1 of the Code. A clerical amendment will be made to the table of parts to reflect this addition. The amendments made by this section apply to property acquired after the enactment of this Act.
